raw_text:
Melzer shocks Agassi in San Jose
 
 Second seed Andre Agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat by Jurgen Melzer in the quarter-finals of the SAP Open.
 
 Agassi was often bamboozled by the Austrian's drop shots in San Jose, losing 6-3 6-1. Defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick rallied to beat Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 3-6 7-6 (8-6) 7-5. But unseeded Cyril Saulnier beat the fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2 6-4 and Tommy Haas overcame eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7) 7-6 (7-3) 6-2. Melzer has now beaten Agassi in two of their three meetings.
 
 "I had a good game plan and I executed it perfectly," he said. "It's always tough to come out to play Andre. "I didn't want him to play his game. He makes you run like a dog all over the court." And Agassi, who was more than matched for power by his opponent's two-handed backhand, said Melzer was an example of several players on the tour willing to take their chances against him. "A lot more guys are capable of it now," said the American. "He played much better than me. That's what he did both times. "I had opportunities to loosen myself up," Agassi added. "But I didn't convert on the big points."

Agassi was beaten by Melzer in San Jose and lost to Andy Roddick, but won against Cyril Saulnier and Tommy Haas.

Melzer has now beaten Agassi twice in three matches.

Saulnier and Haas overcame Mirnyi and Max Mirnyi respectively.
Agassi beat Melzer in two of their three meetings.
Agassi said he had good game plans but was not as strong against Melzer, who made more powerful backhands than his opponent.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Andre Agassi lost to Jurgen Melzer in the quarter-finals of the San Jose SAP Open, 6-3 6-1; Andy Roddick defeated Thomas Enqvist, 3-6 7-6 (8-6) 7-5; Cyril Saulnier beat Vincent Spadea, 6-2 6-4; Tommy Haas won against Max Mirnyi, 6-7 (2-7) 7-6 (7-3) 6-2.

Agassi praised Melzer's ability to adapt to Agassi's power-based game, highlighting that it has become more common for players on tour to take risks against him due to his strength; he also noted he had good execution but failed to fully exploit opportunities to loosen up.

Melzer has won two of their three meetings.

tinyllama:1.1b: Melzer shocked Agassi with a dominant performance in the quarter-finals of the SAP Open, winning all three sets by a comfortable margin against the second seed, Thomas Enqvisst.

The Frenchman Vincent Spadea beat defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick comfortably 6-2, 6-4, while Swiss Tommy Haas overcame eightth seed Max Mirnyi in two sets 6-7 (3-7), 7-6 (7-3) and 6-7 (1-5), respectively.
Melzer's opponent, Andre Agassi, was outclassed by his Austrian rival who won all three sets with ease 6-3, 6-1 and 6-5.
Despite being the less accomplished player, Melzer showed that he has a knack of taking advantage of aggressive opponents.
The results highlight the evolution in the sport, where several players are willing to take their chances against Agassi.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The SAP Open quarter-finals were a close encounter between Andre Agassi and Jurgen Melzer, with both players delivering spirited performances.
The match started with an unexpected combination of power and finesse by the Austrian, who seemed to have the advantage in terms of variety and execution of his game plan.
However, this did not prove to be enough for Andre Agassi, who was eventually overwhelmed by the relentless attacks of Jurgen Melzer.
The result saw the second seed, Andre Agassi, suffer a defeat at the hands of Jurgen Melzer.
Despite being outplayed on multiple occasions, Agassi still managed to keep his cool and remained committed to his game plan throughout the match.

granite3.1-dense:2b: In the SAP Open quarter-finals in San Jose, second seed Andre Agassi lost to unseeded Jurgen Melzer 6-3, 6-1.

Melzer's deceptive drop shots confused Agassi, who expressed frustration that he didn't convert his big opportunities despite not playing his usual aggressive game due to the Austrian's powerful two-handed backhand.
This marks the second consecutive defeat of Agassi against Melzer in their three matches.
Meanwhile, defending champion Andy Roddick advanced by defeating Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5, and unseeded Cyril Saulnier upset fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4.
Tommy Haas overcame eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2.
